I’ll list 5 general steps applicable to most cases.1. Assess your foundationWhile web developers come from different backgrounds, understanding the foundation of software engineering is generally recommended - especially for larger organizations.Let’s say you’re building an ERP, a CRM, a large wiki for a corporation hosting millions of entries which are accessible by different roles and edited simultaneously.The only way to handle that efficiently is understanding the underlying server infrastructure, load balancers, RAID storages, what impact everything has on CPU, RAM, I/O operations, how does the web server spin processes, what are effective ways to cache database queries and the like.The rest is general programming knowledge which is always applicable - loops, conditional statements, functions, OOP, standard algorithms.2. Revise your technical stackIf you program in PHP, you will have to learn a completely new programming language for software development. Same goes for Node.js, probably Python or Ruby (although you can technically build a software app in any of those).It’s a bit easier if you do web development in Java or ASP.NET since both stacks are cross-platform and the transition would be simpler.You can look for specific guides on “transitioning from web development to desktop programming” or programming language comparison guides. It may seem dumb at first, but it’s a quick way to apply your existing knowledge and understand the semantic differences between languages and environments.Figure out what goes into a web application - setting up a web server, a database server, building the front-end and back-end separately and the like. You may already have some experience with RESTful applications or other concepts that are applicable to software development.3. Review your new technological stackYou have probably picked a specific technical stack - if you’re assigned to build a project in a few months from now or want to join a specific organization.Applying the previous step would be a good entry point. Find out what skills are directly applicable to the new platform and what you would need to learn.For instance, a PHP developer working with MySQL may look for a Swing or JavaFX with Oracle or Windows Presentation Foundation with MS SQL. There are certain similarities that you can pick quickly and learn the foundations of building a web application in the first place.Some desktop applications are merely a front-end layer for a cloud infrastructure. You may still need to build a service-oriented infrastructure in the cloud using your existing skills and simply provide a desktop app for accessing and updating these.Others are products shipped to tens of thousands of people. Releasing a new version follows different paradigms since people may run different versions of your product at the same time. You need to ensure backward compatibility and support various versions of the same desktop application.Your application may support different platforms as well - different Windows versions or Windows, macOS, Linux. This may require you to dive deeper into cross-platform challenges - which kinda resemble front-end development across different browsers and OS, too.4. Build an actual projectBuild a pet project with your new technical stack.Pick a programming book, watch some YouTube videos, enroll in an online course. You can combine a few of those and fill in the gaps.You can browse for existing GitHub projects built on your preferred technical stack and figure out how to structure the files and folders, how to set up your configuration, a sample database schema and migration scripts and separating the business layer from the rest.Start with your strength - set up the database layer, build some simple forms and take it from there.
